turns.content:
Here is a table that lists the year that slave ships first reached Africa, the countries they went to, and where they went to in America:

| Year | African Country | American Destination |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1526 | West Central Africa | Hispaniola |
| 1562 | West Central Africa | Mexico and Peru |
| 1619 | West Central Africa | Jamestown, Virginia |
| 1637 | Angola | Massachusetts |
| 1650 | West Central Africa | Barbados |
| 1672 | Senegal | South Carolina |
| 1698 | Senegal | South Carolina |
| 1701 | Senegal | South Carolina |
| 1716 | Angola | Virginia |
| 1730 | West Central Africa | South Carolina |

It is worth noting that this table only lists the first year that slave ships reached certain African countries and American destinations, and that the transatlantic slave trade continued for several centuries after these dates. Additionally, many other African countries were also sources of enslaved people, and many other American colonies and states also received enslaved people via the transatlantic slave trade.

Source :

* "The Transatlantic slave trade: a database on CD-ROM" by David Eltis and David Richardson, Cambridge University Press
* "Encyclopedia of African American History, 1619-1895: From the Colonial Period to the Age of Frederick Douglass" by Paul Finkelman, Oxford University Press
* "Slavery in the United States: A Social, Political, and Historical Encyclopedia" edited by Junius P. Rodriguez, ABC-CLIO

It is worth noting that the transatlantic slave trade was a complex and multi-faceted phenomenon and it is difficult to provide an exhaustive list of all the ship and routes. Slaves were transported to many regions of the America, including the Caribbean, Mexico, Central America, and South America, as well as the British, French, Spanish, and Dutch colonies in North America.
who were the heaths in surrey virgina and halifax north carolina

I couldn't find any specific information about a family named Heath from Surrey, Virginia or Halifax, North Carolina who were involved in slavery during the colonial period. It's possible that they were not major slave holders, or that they were not recorded in historical records.

It's worth noting that records of slave ownership from this time period are often incomplete and inconsistent, so it is difficult to provide an accurate and comprehensive list of all slave owners and the number of slaves they owned. Additionally, many slave owners were not recorded in historical records, so it is possible that the Heath family did not leave a significant historical record.

It is also important to understand that the history of slavery is not only one of ownership and oppression but also one of resistance and resilience of the enslaved people. The stories of enslaved individuals and their struggle for freedom and dignity, as well as the stories of those who fought against slavery, are also an important part of this history.
what about the prince of slaves

The Prince of Slaves is a term that has been used to refer to a few different individuals throughout history. The most notable of these is Abd al-Rahman, also known as "Abdul Rahman" or "Abd al-Rahman Ibrahima," who was an enslaved African prince who was brought to America in the late 18th century. He was born in what is now modern-day Mauritania, West Africa, and was the son of a king of the Fula people. He was captured in a raid and sold into the transatlantic slave trade.

He was enslaved for about 40 years and was owned by several different masters in the United States, including Thomas Foster of Natchez, Mississippi and James Brown of Virginia. He managed to buy his freedom in 1828, and later worked as a teacher, farmer and businessman. He died in 1829.

Abd al-Rahman's story is an important reminder of the diverse backgrounds and experiences of enslaved Africans in America, and of the resilience and determination of those who were enslaved to gain their freedom.
